title: Comparing &[u8] is ~3x slower on Windows

labels.name: I-slow
labels.description: Problems and improvements with respect to performance of generated code.

body:
My initial description of this focused too much on `fastcmp` and confused a lot of people. Update here: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/90360#issuecomment-956563763

---

Someone shared this crate in the Rust community Discord server: https://github.com/saschagrunert/fastcmp

At first look, this shouldn't help. The trait method compiles to 65.6 kB of code, for goodness' sake. And, on Linux, it doesn't. The benchmarks report this:
```
test fast_compare_equal    ... bench:          10 ns/iter (+/- 0) = 25600 MB/s
test fast_compare_unequal  ... bench:          10 ns/iter (+/- 0) = 25600 MB/s
test slice_compare_equal   ... bench:          10 ns/iter (+/- 0) = 25600 MB/s
test slice_compare_unequal ... bench:          10 ns/iter (+/- 0) = 25600 MB/s
```
Except... On Windows (`x86_64-pc-windows-msvc`):
```
test fast_compare_equal    ... bench:           9 ns/iter (+/- 0) = 28444 MB/s
test fast_compare_unequal  ... bench:           9 ns/iter (+/- 0) = 28444 MB/s
test slice_compare_equal   ... bench:          29 ns/iter (+/- 1) = 8827 MB/s
test slice_compare_unequal ... bench:          29 ns/iter (+/- 0) = 8827 MB/s
```

🤯 

I have a fair bit of experience profiling programs on Linux; enough to know exactly what's going on there: a huge jump table, each arm a long chain of move+compare+jump. I don't have a godbolt link because the builds time out trying to optimize this crate. But I have no insight at all into what's happening on Windows. Is the MSVC `memcmp` really just 3x slower?

---
